II. 

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

The  Government’s  poverty  reduction  framework1  notes  the  importance  of  rural 
2. 
electrification  (RE):  “Without  access  to  electricity,  rural  areas  cannot  host  the  industries  and 
other off-farm income-generating activities that are essential to a pro-poor process of structural 
change.” In this respect, the goal is to have 80% of the country’s population electrified by 2010. 
However, the poverty reduction framework also stresses the need to control fiscal deficits so as 
to maintain a stable macroenvironment. In this regard, there is a need for better management of 
public enterprises, including those in the power sector. Efficiencies in the power sector are to be 
achieved  through  unbundling  of  the  relevant  public  enterprises  into  separate  generation, 
transmission, and distribution companies, as outlined in the Government’s 1998 Power Sector 
Policy  Directions.2  The  Government  has  requested  assistance  from  the  Asian  Development 
Bank (ADB) to further electrification of the nation’s rural areas and to support the reform of the 
power sector. 
 
In response to the Government’s request, ADB included the Power Sector Development 
3. 
Program  (the  Program)  in  the  Sri  Lanka  Country  Program  for  2002.  In  preparation  for  the 
Program,  ADB  approved  a  technical  assistance  (TA)3  grant  to  advise  the  Government  on  the 
structure,  operations,  and  management  of  the  power  sector  and  the  entities  within  the  sector. 
An ADB Appraisal Mission visited Sri Lanka from 4 to 25 June 2002. Using the results of the TA, 
the  Government  adopted  a  reform  program  and  issued  a  development  policy  letter  requesting 
ADB's assistance (Appendix 1). 
 
A. 

Sector Description and Performance 

4. 
The power sector in Sri Lanka consists primarily of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) its 
subsidiary, Lanka Electricity Company (LECO), and three independent power producers (IPPs). 
The  key  sector  indicators  are  in  Appendix  2.  CEB  is  a  vertically  integrated,  state-owned  utility 
with about 14,392 employees serving 2.69 million customers. Appendix 3 gives its organization 
chart.  CEB  is  under  the  jurisdiction  of  the  Ministry  of  Power  and  Energy  (MOPE),  and  it  is 
responsible for (i) over 90% of all generation, (ii) transmission of power for the public throughout 
the  nation,  and  (iii)  distribution  of  electricity  to  about  85%  of  all  customers.  The  balance  is 
served  by  LECO,  which  has  342,054  customers  and  a  staff  of  1,321.  In  recent  years,  some 
microhydro  stations  have  been  deployed,  but  they  have  yet  to  make  any  real  impact  on  the 
sector.  
 
5. 
CEB’s  total  installed  capacity  for  electricity  generation  increased  from  1,410  megawatt 
(MW) in 1994 to 1,999 MW in 2001, and now comprises 1,137 MW of hydropower and 563 MW 
of  thermal  power.  The  peak  demand  in  2001  was  1,445  MW,  which  increased  by  2.8% 
compared with 1,405 MW in 2000. The share of private IPPs in the total capacity increased from 
6%  in  1999  to  10%  in  2000.  With  the  increase  in  private  thermal  power  capacity,  reliance  on 
installed capacity of hydropower, further dropped to 57%from 62% a year ago.

In  2000  and  2001,  reduced  hydropower  generation  and  a  turbulent  crude  oil  market 
6. 
adversely affected the energy supply. As a result, CEB had to hire, at a high cost, several power 
plants  from  the  private  sector  on  a  temporary  basis  to  meet  the  demand.    To  ensure  load 
growth, significant new generation capacity needs to be commissioned in the near future. Of the 
expected  165  MW  combined  gas  turbine  at  Kelanitissa,  110  MW  was  commissioned  in 
November  2001.  The  70  MW  Kukule  hydropower  project  is  expected  to  be  commissioned  in 
2004. The 150 MW Upper Kotmale hydropower project loan agreements have been signed but 
no ground-breaking yet, and the 300-MW coal thermal power project is still uncertain.  
 
7. 
Transmission  systems  at  voltage  levels  of  220  kilovolts  (kV)  and  132  kV  are  used  to 
transfer  power  from  the  generation  stations  to  the  load  centers.  The  System  Control  Center 
located  at  Dematagoda  manages  the  operation  of  both  220  kV  and  132  kV  transmission 
systems  of  CEB.  The  transmission  system  is  generally  sound,  but  is  becoming  overloaded  in 
meeting  the  load  growth  in  several  areas.  The  physical  condition  of  the  subtransmission  and 
distribution networks was generally unsatisfactory in the 1990s as a result of high load growth, 
insufficient  investment,  and  inadequate  maintenance.  To  analyze  these  problems,  the 
Distribution Planning Unit of CEB formulated a computerized database in 2000 to collect power 
system data such as voltage drop, phase current, and distribution transformer loading from each 
area office and the customer service centers in all provinces. Development programs to improve 
system  loss  reduction  and  low  voltage  have  been  identified.  Additional  investments  for 
expanding the transmission and distribution systems as well as for the development programs 
are required.  
 
8. 
During the past 10 years, CEB’s system loss was between 17% and 19% mainly due to 
inappropriate network design and metering deficiencies. System loss has gradually increased to 
22%, despite substantial investments made to the transmission and distribution networks. The 
rapid  expansion  of  RE  programs,  delays  in  fixing  breakdowns,  and  lack  of  electricity  meters 
account for the increase in system losses. Hence, it is very important for CEB to reduce such 
losses  to  12%  through  improvements  in  the  power  system  and  careful  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) of the system. 
 
9. 
Recognizing  the  need  for  power  sector  reform,  the  Government  approved  in  1998  the 
adoption  of  a  restructuring  model,  which  called  for  the  unbundling  of  the  power  sector  into 
separate  companies  for  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution.  Furthermore,  through  its 
steering committee for power sector reforms, the Government approved on 6 April 2001 the new 
power sector structure. The approved unbundling of CEB and LECO calls for the establishment 
of  (i)  one  generation  company,  (ii)  one  transmission  company  with  two  subsidiaries  for  bulk 
power  activities  (purchase  and  sale  of  electricity)  and  the  transmission  activity,  and  (iii)  four 
distribution companies. An independent regulator will be established to regulate all the activities 
of  the  new  power  sector  structure.  The  Government  has  decided  to  establish  a  multisector 
regulatory commission, by enacting the Public Utilities Commission Bill, which initially will cover 
infrastructure sectors such as the electricity and water sectors. 
 
B. 

Issues and Opportunities 

10. 
The  power  sector  in  Sri  Lanka  is  faced  with  three  major  constraints  that  need  urgent 
attention.  These  are  (i)  overall  generation  and  load  capacities,  (ii)  financial  management  and 
operational  governance  of  CEB,  and  (iii)  the  business  environment  of  the  sector.  The 
constraints are interlinked in the day-to-day operations of CEB, but they must be delinked during 
analysis and correction for optimum results. 
 

  

 

 3

1. 

Constraints 

11. 
Load  Restrictions.  Power  demand  increased  by  2.8%  in  2001.  Drought  severely 
affected the energy supply from hydroelectric power stations in 2001. Besides the drought, the 
average plant load factor of the thermal power plant was only 46%. This low figure may imply 
inadequate  maintenance  work.  The  insufficient  installed  thermal  power  generation  capacity 
along  with  its  relatively  low  availability  and  the  severe  drought  compelled  CEB  to  resort 
extensively  to  expensive  thermal  power  generation,  mainly  container-mounted  power  plants. 
The total hired generation in 2001 was 341 gigawatt-hours (GWh) accounting for about 5.2% of 
the  total  generation.  The  situation  may  not  improve  in  the  immediate  future  since  the 
commitments  of  the  new  power  plants  such  as  the  Coal  Thermal  Power  Project  and 
Kerawalipitya Power Project are still awaited. 
 
12. 
Financial Management and Governance. The financial management system in CEB is 
antiquated and is based on accounting for expenses incurred and booking them in the proper 
accounts. CEB has not adopted modern business practices in cash management and treasury 
operations  since  CEB's  internal  view  is  that  it  has  so  far  not  been  central  to  its  mission.  In 
addition,  CEB  has  felt  no  need  or  obligation  to  address  this  shortcoming  earlier  since  it  had 
produced enough energy and had substantial amounts of soft loans. As a result, there is today 
no management information system that can provide the management or the board of directors 
information necessary for decision-making in an accurate, up-to-date, and integrated manner. 
 
13. 
CEB  lacks  an  integrated  energy  accounting  system  where  the  amount  of  energy 
generated  is  linked  to  the  actual  energy  billed,  and  in  turn  to  the  cash  collected  monthly. 
Developing  proper  departmental  and  divisional  financial  budgets,  treasury  operations  plans; 
increasing the speed of cash collection, cash placements, and payments made on due dates so 
as  to  utilize  the  credit  terms  given  will  be  highly  beneficial  to  CEB’s  financial  operation  and 
control.  
 
14. 
CEB  Operations.  CEB  today  is  run  more  like  a  government  department  than  an 
autonomous corporation and lacks clear operational and financial objectives. The independence 
and  effectiveness  of  the  board  of  directors  have  not  turned  out  as  originally  intended  and  the 
authority levels within CEB are too low and inadequate for almost any purchase appropriate to 
those levels. The requirements of public service management, particularly those justified by the 
Finance  Act  and  various  regulations,  are  at  the  root  of  many  of  the  problems  in  procurement 
and human resource management, and the absence of management accountability for results. 
The poor focus on customer service translates to low quality of electricity supplies; inconvenient 
billing  processes;  and  slow  response  to  inquiries,  fault  notices,  and  applications  for  new 
connections.  In  addition,  CEB  operations  have  been  guided  by  politically  motivated  directions 
from  MOPE  rather  than  by  the  board's  own  financial  and  operational  needs.  As  a  result,  CEB 
has  not  applied  to  MOPE  for  necessary  tariff  increases,  and  the  need  for  decisions  related  to 
additional generation capacity is needed. 
 

2. 

The Government’s Objectives and Strategy 

15. 
Through its Power Sector Policy Directions in 1998, the Government clearly expressed 
its wish to restructure the power sector so as to create an enabling business environment that 
would improve the sector’s (i) operating efficiencies, (ii) financial viability, and (iii) service to its 
customers.  This  Government  objective  is  even  stronger  today  due  to  the  current  financial 
problems  and  the  need  for  further  generation  capacity.  To  achieve  its  aim,  the  Government 
proposes  to  (i)  encourage  and  facilitate  direct  and  indirect  (benchmark)  competition,  wherever 

 4 

 

 

feasible;  (ii)  invite  private  sector  participation  in  power  generation  through  transparent  and 
competitive  bidding  processes,  with  equal  opportunities  to  the  public  and  private  sectors, 
(iii) charge  tariffs  based  on  commercial  principles  that  enable  costs  to  be  recovered  and 
reasonable  returns  to  be  made  on  investments;  and  (iv)  grant  transparent,  reasonable,  direct 
and  quantified  subsidies  to  targeted  sections  of  consumers.  The  Government  decided  to 
comprehensively amend the existing legislation, regulations, and tariffs in accordance with the 
above principles.  
 
The  Government  established  the  Steering  Committee  for  Power  Sector  Reform4  to 
16. 
oversee  and  approve  matters  related  to  power  sector  restructuring.  To  assist  the  steering 
committee,  the  Power  Sector  Reform  Office  was  established  and  staffed  with  personnel  from 
CEB  and  LECO.  To  address  the  foregoing  objectives,  the  Government  requested  technical 
assistance  from  ADB  and  the  World  Bank  (WB).  The  three  parties  agreed  to  a  delineation  of 
tasks. ADB approved in December 1998 a TA5 for the operational and managerial aspects of a 
restructured power sector, while WB funded the legal and regulatory aspects. The consultants 
began work in the field in early May 2000. As a result of the work presented by the consultants

The new power sector structure would transform CEB into one generating company (GENCO) 
and a transmission company (TRANSCO) that would be responsible for both the transmission 
function  inclusive  of  dispatch  and  the  bulk  power  purchase  and  sales  from  all  generation

fully  owned  by  the  Government,  but  private  sector  participation  will  be  allowed  later  when  the 
companies need funding for future investments.

The  overall  strategy  of  the  program  loan  as  formulated  is  to  address  bottlenecks  to

consumers  will  be  directly  affected  by  tariff  increases,  the  main  beneficiaries  will  be  the 
population residing in unserved areas. These areas are currently not beneficiaries of subsidized 
electricity tariffs, but are indirectly paying for them in terms of taxes, forgone access to electricity 
or other forgone investments. The full poverty impact assessment prepared for the Program is 
presented  in  Supplementary  Appendix  C.  The  data  show  that  unserved  areas  are  among  the 
most economically deprived, with the highest proportion of poor people in Sri Lanka. Inflationary 
pressures  on  consumer  prices  due  to  tariff  increases  can  be  expected  in  the  short  term. 
However,  the  alternative  scenario,  with  CEB  exacerbating  the  fiscal  deficit,  is  likely  to  lead  to 
more widespread and persistent inflation.

85. 
In  the  financial  analysis  of  the  project  component  (Appendix  13)  the  RE  is  financially

the financial benefits gained from the outputs of the component, as the Project caters mainly to 
poor  rural  consumers.  In  ADB’s  experience  with  RE  projects,  the  FIRR  calculations  are 
negative, but the financial loss directly attributed to the Project is outweighed by the substantial 
economic benefits, both direct and indirect as described in the next section.

86. 
The  overall  strategy  of  the  proposed  Project  is  to  address  bottlenecks  to  economic 
growth and to the delivery a high-quality supply of electricity to the unserved population. On the 
one  hand,  the  inefficiency  and  financial  losses  of  CEB  reduce  its  ability  to  pursue  RE  and 
maintain a high-quality supply to rural areas. On the other, the deterioration of CEB exacerbates 
the  severe  fiscal  deficit  that  raises  concern  about  future  ability  of  the  Government  to  invest  in 
sectors more productive for economic growth and poverty reduction. Although funds are not fully 
fungible, the linkage between fiscal space and CEB’s losses is clear. The opportunity costs of 
the financial cash shortfall of CEB in terms of social sector spending amounts to 22% for fiscal 
year 2001. 
87. 
In  the  absence  of  sector  reform  and  necessary  tariff  increases,  the  situation  can  only 
worsen. While all categories of electricity consumers will be directly affected by tariff increases, 
the  main  beneficiaries  will  be  the  population  residing  in  unserved  areas.  These  areas  are 
currently not beneficiaries of the subsidized electricity tariffs, but are indirectly paying for them in 
terms of forgone access to electricity or other forgone investments. The need for tariff increases 
will  result  in  inflationary  pressures  on  the  general  price  level  in  the  short  term.  However,  the 
alternative is dismal. Fiscal imbalances not only result in inflation but also act to reduce investor 
confidence  in  the  economy.  Government  and  CEB  borrowing  from  the  banking  sector  further 
crowds  out  private  investments  and  raises  the  interest  rate.  The  consequences  of  no  sector 
reform on economic growth and poverty reduction would devastate the Sri Lankan economy. 
 

b. 

Project Component  

88. 
In the economic analysis of the RE investments (Appendix 13) the benefits derive from 
two  sources:  (i)  the  replacement  costs  of  alternative  energy  sources  that  would  be  used  for 
lighting in the absence of electricity, and (ii) the incremental benefits from increased electricity 
consumption.  Residential  consumers  whose  primary  use  for  electricity  is  for  lighting  are 
differentiated by household size. Industrial users, on the other hand, use power for machinery in 
addition  to  lighting.  Overall,  the  RE  investments  have  an  EIRR  of  23.6%,  with  the  bulk  of  the 
benefits coming from the additional power consumed. Sensitivity analysis of the level of system 
losses,  mix  of  hydro  and  thermal  generation,  and  price  of  oil  show  that  the  RE  investments 
achieve an EIRR in excess of 20% even under conservative assumptions. 
 
89. 
The economic analysis considers only a narrow range of project benefits. Unquantifiable 
benefits  of  electrification  include  a  variety  of  dimensions  of  social  and  economic  well-being. 
Targeted project beneficiaries will benefit directly through substantial cost savings on alternative 
energy sources, and savings in time and effort for household activities. Newly electrified villages 
in the rural areas where the provision of electricity lays the foundation for structural change and 
economic  growth  undergo  fundamental  economic  transformation.  Electrification  enhances  the

reducing income deprivation among the poor. In addition, the diversified income sources reduce 
vulnerability. The detailed poverty reduction and social strategy is presented in Appendix 14.

Private  sector  is  expected  to  play  a  key  role  in  power  sector  development  activities. 
Developers  will  be  invited  to  build  power  generation  plants  that  are  elements  of  the  approved 
plan. The selection will be through a transparent competitive bidding process. In support of this, 
the  Government's  approach  will  be  to  foster  a  business  environment  that  will  provide  a  level 
playing field both for the private and public sectors and also by separating sector regulation from 
operations.  It 
is  recognized,  however,  that  to  provide  incentives  for  better  technical 
performance,  there  has  to  be  competition  and  an  appropriate  enabling  commercial  business 
environment. As already mentioned earlier, the Government proposes to establish the Sri Lanka 
Public  Utilities  Commission,  a  multisector  regulatory  commission  to  make  tariff  setting  and 
regulation,  transparent  and  apolitical.  The  private  sector  involvement  can  already  be  seen 
through the establishment of various medium-size power stations by the private sector, the AES 
Kelanatissa independent power station, the development of the Kerewalipitiya power station and 
the  GOSL's  decision  to  increase  the  limit  on  private  sector  participation  for  development  of 
hydro generation from 10MW to 50MW. 
 
D. 
 
8. 
The  Government  of  Sri  Lanka  recognizes  the  fact  that  there  has  to  be  a  tariff 
rationalization  if  private  and  foreign  investments  are  to  be  forthcoming  in  the  power  sector. 
Utilities  should  operate  on  commercial  principles  and  earn  adequate  rates  of  return  on  capital 
investments. On the other hand, grant of unrestrained freedom to fix the tariff by power utilities 
will  lead  to  consumer  interest  being  adversely  affected.  Looking  to  this  we  have  set  up  an 
independent regulatory commission. While the Government of Sri Lanka recognizes, on the one 
hand,  the  need  for  the  continuance  of  subsidized  tariff  for  socially  obligatory  activities  like 
drinking water and street lighting and lighting for urban and rural poor, on the other hand, it also 
recognizes that these subsidies will have to be explicit, quantified, reasonable and targeted and 
paid  for  by  the  Government  as  part  of  its  social  obligations.  The  Government  also  recognizes 
that,  while  cross-subsidization  cannot  be  fully  eliminated,  it  has  to  be  kept  within  reasonable 
limits. To assure the ADB of our commitment to these principles the Government has agreed to 
pay  the  Ceylon  Electricity  Board  for  the  electricity  supplied  by  it  for  street  lighting,  until  and 
including 31 August 2002, and will provide, through the Government's budget, additional funds 
to pay for such social activities on a recurring basis every year. In addition, action will be taken 
to settle all dues to the Ceylon Electricity Board from all the private sector institutions.

Poverty Analysis  

Poverty Intervention 

 
 
The rural electrification (RE) component under the proposed loan proposes to electrify about 113,000 
households in 820 villages, in addition to commercial and religious establishments. Nearly 50,000 of these 
households (44%) appear to live below the poverty line. To ensure poverty targeting in the RE component, 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) are discussing amortization of 
connection charges. Although, non electrified households residing in electrified areas do benefit indirectly 
from increased income-generating activities and improved health care, they are deprived of the direct 
benefits. Cost savings, in the short term, are especially significant among these benefits. For poor 
households, electricity expenditure on lighting is reduced by over 50 % on average in addition to the 
benefit of not suffering from bottlenecks in the availability of kerosene in the local store.     
 
 
B. 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Poverty and social assessment for the proposed project was conducted during the feasibility study.  The 
primary objective of this study is to (i) assess whether the benefits of the project will flow primarily to 
poor/nonpoor consumers; (ii) design the poverty intervention component of the project; (iii) identify and 
deal effectively with any social risks such as involuntary resettlement, gender, labor, affordability, including 
the need to prepare any necessary mitigative measures or plan.   
 
Despite the availability of socioeconomic data on RE, CEB needs to update and improve its database to 
capture consumer behavior and long-term benefits.  Although surveys have been conducted under 
previous RE loans, the need to analyze socioeconomic data related to electrification is not understood and 
hence the information that the surveys capture is not effectively used. In addition, obstacles that prevent 
connection by poor households to connect are not appropriately addressed since the existing survey data 
used for analysis do not refer to these issues. The CEB or its successor companies will be responsible for 
monitoring consumer behavior and the benefits from the RE component.  A socioeconomic survey with 
emphasis on the benefits to the poor, including issues related to poverty targeting in the RE schemes, will 
be conducted at the early stage of project implementation and will be updated annually.  The survey data 
will be used to update the current socioeconomic data underlying the economic analysis for individual 
subprojects.  The poverty impact analysis together with the economic criterion of 12% rate of return will 
determine the selection of future subprojects. 
 
 
C. 
 
Stakeholder analysis.  The project is designed through a participatory process.  Different categories of 
stakeholders are identified: government staff, labor unions, and categories of electricity consumers, non-
government organizations (NGOs) and aid communities. Stakeholder analysis was conducted to analyze 
who are likely to be the major beneficiaries of the project and disadvantages from the Project. 
 
Participation  strategy  required.    As  part  of  the  requirements  under  the  proposed  Public  Utilities 
Commission  Bill,  the  Public  Utilities  Commission  will,  where  it  considers  appropriate  to  do  so,  and 
following  consultation  with  the  Minister  of  Power  and  Energy,  establish  as  a  part  of  the  Commission,  by 
order  published  in  the  Gazette,  a  consumer  consultative  committee  (C3)  for  the  following  purposes:  (i) 
advise  the  Commission  on  appropriate  consumer  standards;  (ii)  monitoring  electricity  consumer 
satisfaction; (iii) promote awareness of consumer rights and standards; and (iv) receive and, where it has 
the  power  to  do  so,  deal  with  complaints  and  concerns  of  electricity  consumers.    The  Commission  will 
develop the form, structure, composition, and functions of the C3.
